TXT_KEY_BUILDING_ARABIAN_MADRASSA_PEDIA: A "madrassa" is an Arabic institute of higher learning, usually religious in nature. The earliest madrasses were formed in Islamic mosques, where scholars gathered to study and debate religious and secular issues of the day. Over time students would come to study with the most learned scholars; the most popular teachers often had to construct separate buildings to hold their growing student population.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]At the madrassas the students would learn to read and write and study religious doctrine, history and law. Some madrassas also taught logic, world history, foreign language, mathematics, art and science. Since state-run colleges and universities did not appear until later in history, the madrassas were critical centers of learning in many early Arabic cities.
TXT_KEY_BUILDING_CHINESE_PAVILLION_PEDIA: A "pavilion" is a covered building without surrounding walls (think of it as a roof supported by columns). This kind of structure has been extremely popular for centuries in China, where they are often found in parks and gardens as well as in temple complexes. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The first Chinese pavilions were probably constructed during the "Zhou dynasty," and they became quite numerous during the Warring States Period (approximately 400-200 BC). At first these buildings may have been used as watchtowers, providing soldiers with an uninterrupted 360-degree view along with shelter from rain and snow, but in later periods they were incorporated into Chinese gardens and parks, where they were prized for their elegance and simplicity of design.
TXT_KEY_BUILDING_FRENCH_SALON_PEDIA: In the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries, the French nobility used to gather the local "intelligentsia" to discuss the literary or artistic works of the day. The word "salon" refers to the reception room where these parties were held. The salons were almost always organized by the most beautiful, intelligent and rich women in the French nobility. During the seventeenth centuries the two most important literary salons were run by Madame de Rambouillet and her rival, Madeleine de Scudery. Virtually every important French author, poet, artist and scientist attended one or the other of these gatherings, making them the very centers of French intellectual thought.
TXT_KEY_BUILDING_GERMAN_ASSEMBLY_PLANT_P: An assembly plant is a building or complex of buildings where workers build goods from their component parts, which are created on-the-spot or in factories elsewhere. In many cases the goods are assembled using an "assembly line" style of production in which individual parts are added to the product by a number of workers, each of whom performs his or her actions in sequence as the product moves down the production line. The plant also may include a warehouse to store parts as well as the finished products.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Although a relative latecomer to the Industrial Revolution and manufacturing in general, by the early twentieth century the German plants were among the most efficient in the world. During the First and Second World Wars German plants built thousands of tanks, planes, and other war materiel under horrendous conditions and in the face of concentrated Allied bombing attacks. Into the twenty-first century the German manufactories remain among the world's best.
TXT_KEY_BUILDING_GREEK_ODEON_PEDIA: Modern western drama was created in Greece around 530 BC, evolving from the "dithyramb," a fertility ritual of songs, poems and dances offered to the Greek god Dionysus. An "Odeon" is a large, open-aired structure in which such performances were held. The audience sat in a semicircle of seats around a central paved "dancing square" (orchestra). The first row of seats was reserved for important officials or priests. There was usually an altar dedicated to Dionysus somewhere in the odeon. The "logeion" was a small raised platform where the performers acted (the original dramas had at most three or four actors; the size of the stage would increase as later plays required bigger casts).
TXT_KEY_BUILDING_INCAN_TERRACE_PEDIA: Much of the Incan empire was located on the steep slopes of the Andes Mountains. Such terrain posed a significant challenge to agriculture, as constant soil erosion made the ground less fertile, and heavy rains were quite likely to wash away the current crops (as well as the soil they stood on). Very early on, the Incan farmers mastered the art of constructing terraces upon which to grow their crops. These terraces created much flatter ground upon which to farm, which resulted in less soil erosion and greatly increased production.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Creation of farming terraces in such steep terrain required a good deal of engineering skill (to build the necessary retaining walls), as well as an abundance of cheap manual labor and a sophisticated knowledge of irrigation. They were well worth the effort, however, and with them the Incans were able to sustain thriving cities in locations that other civilizations would have found totally inhospitable.
TXT_KEY_BUILDING_INDIAN_MAUSOLEUM_PEDIA: A "mausoleum" is a large and ornate building constructed to hold the remains of a person of importance, typically a leader, warlord, or extremely wealthy merchant. Mausoleums can be found in many ancient civilizations, where they played both a sacred and political role - seeking to awe the viewer with the power and wealth of the state (or the individual). The Egyptian pyramids are essentially huge mausoleums built to hold the remains of pharaohs.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Throughout history Indian leaders have constructed extensive mausoleums for themselves and their relatives. Perhaps the best known of these is the Taj Mahal, built in the seventeenth century by the Mughal Emperor Shah Jahan to house the remains of his beloved wife, Mumtaz Mahal.
TXT_KEY_BUILDING_JAPANESE_SHALE_PLANT_PE: In the early half of the twentieth century, Japan was fast becoming one of the most industrialized nations in the world. As such, Japan needed access to fossil fuels to run her factories, energy plants, and vehicles, especially her growing navy. Much of Japan's colonization/conquest efforts during that period were designed to gain control over areas rich in such resources. Conflict between Japan and the United States - another growing Pacific industrial power - over these resources was one of the root causes of the Second World War (or the Pacific theatre portion of that war, anyway).[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Shale is a compound formed of decayed and compacted organic material much like other fossil fuels. However, shale requires a good deal of preparation before it becomes an adequate fuel, making it much more expensive than petroleum. However, lacking easy access to high-quality coal and petroleum during the pre-war period, the Japanese constructed a number of plants designed to create fuel from shale. The shale plant in occupied Manchuria was capable of producing as much as 200,000 tons of shale oil per year. Such plants kept the Japanese navy afloat during its long struggle with the larger and resource-rich United States.
TXT_KEY_BUILDING_MONGOL_GER_PEDIA: As nomadic tribesmen (and later as cavalry-based conquerors), the Mongolians' survival was dependent upon the quality of their horses and the skill of their riders.  A warhorse must be extensively trained if it is to be successfully used in battle. In their natural state, most horses quite sensibly seek to run away from dangerous situations - say, when surrounded by screaming men armed with sharp objects. A cavalryman's horse, on the other hand, needs to be able to suppress this instinct and instead instantly carry out any order given it by its rider - no matter how suicidal. Such training takes time and skill - for both mount and rider. Mongolian stables - built in the ubiquitous Mongolian yurt (or "ger") tents - provide such training.
TXT_KEY_BUILDING_ROMAN_FORUM_PEDIA: Roman civic and commercial life was largely centered upon the "forum," an open space surrounded by markets, temples, government buildings, and the "rostra," a platform where Romans made political speeches to their fellows. The Roman forums may have been modeled upon the "agoras," which served much the same purposes in earlier Greek cities. The most famous forum is the "Roman Forum," located at the center of the Imperial City, but most other Roman cities had them as well.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The Roman Forum in Rome contained a number of very important and beautiful buildings, including temples devoted to Romulus, Saturn and Vesta, several basilicas, and the "Curia Hostilia," which housed the Roman Senate.
TXT_KEY_BUILDING_RUSSIAN_RESEARCH_INSTIT: Russian scientific research has a long and storied history. The great seventeenth century Russian artist and scientist Mikhail Lomonosov (1711-1765) helped create the University of Moscow, one of the great scientific research institutions of the world. Tsar Peter the Great founded the prestigious Russian Academy of Science by decree in 1724.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]When the Communists took over Russia in the early twentieth century they placed great emphasis upon modernizing and industrializing the Soviet Union, and they heavily funded scientific research. Though initially well behind their European and American counterparts, Russian scientists quickly caught up, and in some areas - especially in the theoretical sciences - surpassed their colleagues in the West.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The collapse of the Soviet Union in the latter half of the twentieth century did great damage to scientific research; however, as Russia regains economic strength, it can be expected her scientists, universities and research institutions will once again be among the leaders in the world.
TXT_KEY_BUILDING_SPANISH_CITADEL_PEDIA: Throughout history, men have built fortified structures to protect themselves from external enemies. These structures have taken many forms over the years, from simple ditches and walls to medieval castles to huge and complex "star" fortresses designed to protect against muskets and cannon. Citadels are large castle-like structures built in or adjacent to cities. They are designed to defend the city against external attack, and (often) to protect the city's rulers against internal revolt.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]During the fifteenth through seventeenth centuries, Spain was a mighty colonial power with cities scattered throughout the Caribbean and Central and South America, providing Spain with (among other things) enormous quantities of silver and gold. These cities were under constant threat of attack, both from European fleets and armies as well as from native uprisings. To protect its possessions, the Spanish built a series of mighty citadels in its most important cities. When properly garrisoned and supplied, these were extremely difficult to capture. Remnants of these Spanish citadels can still be seen throughout the New World - El Castillo San Felipe del Morro, in San Juan, Puerto Rico, is a fine example of Spanish defensive works.
TXT_KEY_BUILDING_CARTHAGE_COTHON_PEDIA: Of Phoenician origin, the city-state of Carthage was a mighty sea power, with a trading empire stretching across much of the Mediterranean. Carthage's wealth (and survival) depended upon the quality of its navy and merchant fleet. To protect its fleet from attack and the elements, and to improve and speed construction of new vessels, Carthage constructed two artificial harbors ("cothon") in the city, a massive effort that required the excavation of some 230,000 cubic meters of earth. One harbor was for the merchant fleet; the second was for the Carthaginian navy.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]According to ancient historians, "The harbors had communication with each other, and a common entrance from the sea seventy feet wide, which could be closed with iron chains. The first port was for merchant vessels, and here were collected all kinds of ships' tackle. Within the second port was an island, and great quays were set at intervals round both the harbor and the island. These embankments were full of shipyards which had capacity for 220 vessels."
TXT_KEY_BUILDING_CELTIC_DUN_PEDIA: "Dun" is a Celtic word meaning, "hill-fort." The Celts began constructing duns around the seventh century BC, and remnants can be found scattered across Western Europe, England, Scotland and Ireland. Duns were typically small, squat towers constructed of dry-laid stone on raised, defensible terrain such as hills and promontories. Some were surrounded by ditches or artificial lakes.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]While many hill-forts were primitive and quite small, more extensive and complex Celtic duns have also been discovered. One such example is "Dun Carloway," on the Isle of Lewis, Scotland. This double-walled castle-like structure originally stood some thirteen meters high and fourteen meters in diameter. Maiden Castle in Dorset, England, is an extensive wall and ditch work surmounting a large hill some 47 acres in size.
TXT_KEY_BUILDING_KOREAN_SEOWON_PEDIA: Throughout its history, Korea has always placed great emphasis on education. The first system of formal education was created during the "Three Kingdoms" period (57 BC - 668 AD). This system was loosely based upon the education system used in Korea's northern neighbor, China. The National Confucian Academy (or "seowon"), the first state-run institution of higher learning was founded in 372 AD, and some three hundred years later another university - the National Confucian College - was founded in 660 AD. Early Korean universities emphasized the study of Chinese classics. Confucianism was an important topic of study, and it remained so even after the Koryo Dyansty adopted Buddhism as the state religion.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]In modern Korea (at least in the South) education continues to be held in high importance. There are over 300 institutes of higher education - including junior vocational colleges and colleges and universities and graduate schools - in South Korea, with enrollment in excess of two million students.
TXT_KEY_BUILDING_OTTOMAN_HAMMAM_PEDIA: Cleanliness was extremely important in Ottoman culture. Before modern plumbing, the Ottomans constructed communal steam baths ("hammams") throughout their major cities. In early times many of these were attached to mosques - ritual cleanliness played an important part in the Ottoman religious beliefs - in later periods they evolved into separate buildings and eventually, into enormous complexes of buildings.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The Ottoman hammams were largely modeled on their Roman and Byzantine predecessors. They contained three main areas: a hot room, a moderate room and a cool room. Both men and women could attend hammams, but they bathed in separate areas.
TXT_KEY_BUILDING_VIKING_TRADING_POST_PED: Although they did seek to extend their empire through piracy and invasion, for much of the time the Vikings were merchants, with a trading network that extended from Greenland, Iceland, and Finland into the British Isles, Western Europe, and the Mediterranean. Viking merchants are known to have traded Russian slaves at Constantinople for silks and spices, and they brought furs and ivory from far-away Greenland to ports throughout Europe, North Africa and the Middle East.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The earliest Viking trading posts were quite primitive settlements, consisting of simple dwellings and warehouses constructed of whatever local material was readily available. Over time many of the posts flourished, becoming important cities in their own rights. For example the Irish capitol of Dublin began its existence as a Viking trading post; and after being captured by the Vikings, the English city of York became a thriving trading center, second in importance only to London.
TXT_KEY_BUILDING_ZULU_IKHANDA_PEDIA: Upon ascending to power, the great Zulu leader Shaka implemented a number of important civil and military reforms to his growing civilization. In addition to his important innovations to Zulu warfare - he is often credited with the invention of the famous Zulu "buffalo horns" formation, as well as the introduction of the "iklwa," a short stabbing spear that proved enormously successful in combat - Shaka also reorganized Zulu society to better support his military ambitions.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]At the age of six, young boys joined Shaka's military as apprentice warriors. (This is a surprising parallel to the way that Spartan boys were raised - though it's unlikely that Shaka every heard of the Spartans.) The young warriors were trained in "ikhanda" (special military camps). During their training the Zulu boys were imbued with military fervor, put through rigorous physical exercise, and of course instructed in the use of the Zulu's powerful weapons. In battle they carried supplies and extra weapons for the warriors, and it is believed that they occasionally went out on hit-and-run raids against less dangerous enemy tribes. When the boys reached the appropriate age, they became full-fledged warriors. As a result the Zulu warriors were among the bravest and best-trained soldiers in the world.

TXT_KEY_NEW_GREEKWAR_TECH_ADVANCED_SAILI: [TAB]Although the earliest sailing ships were undoubtedly used for fishing  and transportation, man quickly found ways to turn these vehicles into  weapons. Typically, non-military vessels are no match for dedicated  warships crewed with professional warriors. However, warships are  expensive to build, crew and maintain, and only fairly wealthy - or  bloodthirsty or desperate - nations possess large standing navies.
TXT_KEY_NEW_GREEKWAR_TECH_IMPROVED_FORMA: [TAB]While the spear is a potent weapon in itself, it truly comes into  power when employed in large numbers. Spears get their best effect when  the warriors stand in tight formations, allowing those behind the front  ranks to engage in combat as well. This however requires a good deal of  training - else the soldiers are as dangerous to their cohorts as they are  to the enemy.

[TAB]Spearmen reached their height of potency under the Greeks, who  deployed their men in "phalanxes," remarkably tight formations in which up  to five ranks of soldiers were able to engage the enemy at one time.  Phalanxes required an extraordinary amount of training and discipline.  Eventually as military tactics and technology advanced they would be  supplanted, but in their day they were the undisputed masters of the  ancient battlefield.
TXT_KEY_VIKING_DAWN_OF_MAN_TEXT: The Year is 800 AD and you are the Viking King, Ragnar Lodbrok. The chill of the long winter bites into your fingers as you look over your fleet of longships. These boats will take you across the cold sea to your raiding destination. Do you raid for the money to provide for your children and people? Surely. Do you raid to prove yourself before your god?  Possibly. Do you raid for the adventure? Definitely![PARAGRAPH:1][BOLD]Game Notes:[\BOLD]The Scenario lasts 200 turns. Your goal is to accumulate %d1 gold before the end of the game. Researching treasure locations and then returning these treasures to your capital will increase your gold.

TXT_KEY_NEW_BUILDING_MONUMENT_PEDIA: [TAB]A monument is a structure that reminds people of an important event that occured in the area, or an important person - a famous general or leader, perhaps. Different cultures have constructed monuments out of varied materials - wood, stone, or even precious metals. Generally, the only ancient monuments remaining today are those made out of stone: over time the wooden monuments have decayed, and the ones constructed of precious metals have been looted and destroyed.
TXT_KEY_BUILDING_MONUMENT_STRATEGY: [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Monuments[COLOR_REVERT] provide a small amount of culture, and are a good way to expand city borders early on.

TXT_KEY_CHINESE_UNIFICATION_BUILDING_NAT: The [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]National Wall[COLOR_REVERT] is a national wonder which gives every city a growth boost with +1 Population and +1 Health while also (and perhaps more importantly) preventing barbarians from crossing into your territory.

TXT_KEY_CHINESE_UNIFICATION_CIVICS_PACIF: +200% Great Person generation in cities with State Religion; Military units cost +1 gold to support. Alternative for those who prefer domination through economics and culture rather than armies.
TXT_KEY_CHINESE_UNIFICATION_CIVIC_BUREAU: Provides +50% Production and Commerce in capital city. A well-rounded bonus which can be used for peaceful or wartime purposes.
TXT_KEY_CHINESE_UNIFICATION_CIVIC_NATION: +1 Gold from Village and Town improvements; Can spend gold to finish production. Designed to fuel an economy and make use of the extra money by turning it into production.
TXT_KEY_CHINESE_UNIFICATION_CIVIC_INDEPE: +1 Food from Farm improvements; -33% Military unit production. Allows for a huge population but at the cost of penalties when building up an army.
TXT_KEY_CHINESE_UNIFICATION_TECH_EDUCATE: All cities +2 receive Specialists. A powerful late-game civic which gives a boost to every city's economy.
TXT_KEY_CHINESE_UNIFICATION_CIVICS_BARTE: +15% Commerce in all cities. A general economic upgrade from Decentralization.
TXT_KEY_CHINESE_UNIFICATION_CIVICS_STATE: No Maintenance costs from distance to Capital. Mines, Workshops, Windmills and Watermills provide +1 Food. Good for large empires and those which rely on production-based plot improvements.
TXT_KEY_CHINESE_UNIFICATION_CIVICS_SHAMA: +25% Commerce in Capital and +100% Culture in all cities. Basic religion upgrade available early on.
TXT_KEY_CHINESE_UNIFICATION_CIVICS_DAOIS: All cities receive +1 Happiness from Forest plots. A good option for those suffering from Happiness problems.
TXT_KEY_CHINESE_UNIFICATION_CIVICS_CONFU: All cities receive +2 Health. A way to curb Unhealthiness in cities.
TXT_KEY_CHINESE_UNIFICATION_CIVICS_MOHIS: All cities +33% Science. For those who make this civic a priority it can provide a massive boost to research.
TXT_KEY_CHINESE_UNIFICATION_CIVICS_LEGAL: All new units built receive +4 Experience Points. All cities +1 Unhappiness for each religion present. Enduring the happiness penalty with this civic will allow for a much more experienced and powerful army.
TXT_KEY_CHINESE_UNIFICATION_UNIT_FAMILY_: [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Family Emissaries[COLOR_REVERT] are used to spread family bloodlines to cities, both your own for happiness as well as to those of others in order to gain a diplomatic advantage.
TXT_KEY_NEW_CHINESE_UNIFICATION_UNIT_CHA: The [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Chariot I[COLOR_REVERT] is an early Mounted unit, designed for fast shock attacks, but it is vulnerable to [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Polearm[COLOR_REVERT] units..

The [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Chariot II[COLOR_REVERT] is an improved Mounted unit, designed for fast shock attacks, but remains vulnerable to [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Polearm[COLOR_REVERT] units. It has a slight power advantage over the contemporary [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Heavy Cavalry I[COLOR_REVERT], but costs more and has a smaller chance of retreating.
TXT_KEY_NEW_CHINESE_UNIFICATION_UNIT_HEA: The [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Heavy Cavalry I[COLOR_REVERT] unit is a fast and powerful Mounted unit, but is vulnerable to [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Polearm[COLOR_REVERT] units. It costs slightly less than the [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Chariot II[COLOR_REVERT] and has a higher chance to retreat from a losing battle, but is slightly weaker in combat.

The [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Heavy Cavalry II[COLOR_REVERT] unit is the ultimate Mounted unit, but remains vulnerable to [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Polearm[COLOR_REVERT] units. It is the pinnacle of fast attackers and while expensive, is strong in combat and also possesses the ability to retreat.
TXT_KEY_CHINESE_UNIFICATION_TECH_AGRICUL: Important in developing cities and fostering growth, the [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Agriculture[COLOR_REVERT] tech unlocks the [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Farm[COLOR_REVERT] plot Improvement and [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Granary[COLOR_REVERT] Building.
TXT_KEY_CHINESE_UNIFICATION_TECH_FISHING: The [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Fishing[COLOR_REVERT] tech is important in building up one's economy and allowing use of the seas, allowing cities to work water plots and build the [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Work Boat[COLOR_REVERT] unit.
TXT_KEY_CHINESE_UNIFICATION_TECH_ARCHERY: [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Archery[COLOR_REVERT] is vital for defense and military affairs, allowing the construction of the [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Barracks[COLOR_REVERT] Building and [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Archer I[COLOR_REVERT] unit.
TXT_KEY_CHINESE_UNIFICATION_TECH_DIVINAT: [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Divination[COLOR_REVERT] furthers one's internal development, allowing the creation of the [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Cottage[COLOR_REVERT] plot improvement, [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Library[COLOR_REVERT] Building and the [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Shamanism[COLOR_REVERT] Civic, boosting Commerce and Culture.
TXT_KEY_CHINESE_UNIFICATION_TECH_THE_WHE: [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]The Wheel[COLOR_REVERT] technology has a number of benefits, allowing faster transportation via [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Roads[COLOR_REVERT], the [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Pasture[COLOR_REVERT] plot Improvement and the [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Chariot I[COLOR_REVERT], a fast Mounted unit.
TXT_KEY_CHINESE_UNIFICATION_TECH_MINING_: The [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Mining[COLOR_REVERT] tech has both economic and military purposes, revealing the [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Gold[COLOR_REVERT] bonus, allowing the construction of the [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Mine[COLOR_REVERT] plot Improvement and the [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Polearm I[COLOR_REVERT], an anti-Mounted unit.
TXT_KEY_CHINESE_UNIFICATION_TECH_CROP_RO: [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Crop Rotation[COLOR_REVERT] provides a military boost by unlocking the [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Stable[COLOR_REVERT] Building and [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Feudal Levy[COLOR_REVERT] Civic, allowing military units to be produced with food, and an economic one with the [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Camp[COLOR_REVERT] plot Improvement.
TXT_KEY_CHINESE_UNIFICATION_TECH_SAILING: The [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Sailing[COLOR_REVERT] tech has a number of uses: the [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Galley[COLOR_REVERT] Naval unit can transport units and help crack tough enemy defenses by bombarding cities. It also allows trade over coastal waters and allow the use or construction of a pair of economic Buildings and one Civic.
TXT_KEY_CHINESE_UNIFICATION_TECH_FILIAL_: [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Filial Piety[COLOR_REVERT] is a must for conducting diplomacy with other civs. It unlocks a number of diplomatic options along with the [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Family Altar[COLOR_REVERT], vital for spreading one's 'Family Bloodine' and thus, diplomatic influence.
TXT_KEY_CHINESE_UNIFICATION_TECH_RULE_OF: [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Rule of Heaven[COLOR_REVERT] is a good tech for more peaceful players, allowing the construction of two wonders and the [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Bureaucracy[COLOR_REVERT] Civic which increases Production and Commerce in the Capital.
TXT_KEY_NEW_CHINESE_UNIFICATION_TECH_CIT: The [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]City States[COLOR_REVERT] tech is a good tech for players focused on economic matters, providing happiness with the [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Temple[COLOR_REVERT] Building and [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Daoism[COLOR_REVERT] Civic, and also unlocking the [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Workshop[COLOR_REVERT] plot Improvement.
TXT_KEY_CHINESE_UNIFICATION_TECH_BRONZE_: [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Bronze Working[COLOR_REVERT] is primarily a military tech, revealing the [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Iron[COLOR_REVERT] Bonus and allowing the construction of the production-boosting [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Forge[COLOR_REVERT] Building, but also unlocking the [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Vassalage[COLOR_REVERT] Civic, which provides an XP bonus to new units.
TXT_KEY_CHINESE_UNIFICATION_TECH_MASONRY: The [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Masonry[COLOR_REVERT] technology is good for protecting one's Civ, allowing the defensive [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Walls[COLOR_REVERT] Building as well as the Barbarian-warding [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]National Wall[COLOR_REVERT] wonder. It also unlocks the [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Slavery[COLOR_REVERT] Civic, good for speeding up the construction of Units (or Buildings) at the cost of population.
TXT_KEY_CHINESE_UNIFICATION_TECH_FEUDALI: [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Feudalism[COLOR_REVERT] has a variety of functions, allowing the building of the important anti-Mounted [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Polearm II[COLOR_REVERT] and defensive [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Archer II[COLOR_REVERT] units, while also unlocking two production-based plot Improvements and the [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Serfdom[COLOR_REVERT] Civic, which increases the rate at which [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Workers[COLOR_REVERT] complete tasks.
TXT_KEY_CHINESE_UNIFICATION_TECH_MATHEMA: Primarily a military-tech, [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Mathematics[COLOR_REVERT] allows the defensive [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Fort[COLOR_REVERT] plot Improvement and [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Castle[COLOR_REVERT] Building, also unlocking the anti-Melee [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Crossbowman I[COLOR_REVERT] unit and the [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Free Market[COLOR_REVERT] Civic, which increases the number of Trade Routes for every city.
TXT_KEY_CHINESE_UNIFICATION_TECH_HORSEBA: [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Horseback Riding[COLOR_REVERT] is mostly important for its Mounted [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Heavy Cavalry I[COLOR_REVERT] unit, but also gives Specialists with the [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Mercantilism[COLOR_REVERT] Civic and other bonuses from the [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Grocer[COLOR_REVERT] Building and the [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Heroic Epic[COLOR_REVERT] National Wonder.
TXT_KEY_CHINESE_UNIFICATION_TECH_PHILOSO: A more peaceful tech, [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Philosophy[COLOR_REVERT] enables [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Defensive Pacts[COLOR_REVERT] between Civs, the anti-war [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Pacifism[COLOR_REVERT] and Health-focused [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Confucianism[COLOR_REVERT] Civic but also has some bite with the [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Sun Tzu's Art of War[COLOR_REVERT] World Wonder, which gives new units extra XP.
TXT_KEY_CHINESE_UNIFICATION_TECH_METAL_C: [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Metal Casting[COLOR_REVERT] allows the Mounted [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Chariot II[COLOR_REVERT] unit along with the ability to spread Irrigation to plots without an adjacent source of fresh water.
TXT_KEY_CHINESE_UNIFICATION_TECH_IRON_WO: Important for military-minded players, [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Iron Working[COLOR_REVERT] enables the construction of the city-attacking [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Swordsman I[COLOR_REVERT] unit while additionally unlocking the [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Warrior Houses[COLOR_REVERT] Civic, which allows the drafting of military units and provides Happiness with the [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Barracks[COLOR_REVERT] Building. However, not to be overlooked by those more focused on economics, it also provides the [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Aqueduct[COLOR_REVERT] Building, increasing the Health in a city.
TXT_KEY_CHINESE_UNIFICATION_TECH_INDEPEN: Very much focused on internal improvement, the [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Independent Farmers[COLOR_REVERT] technology speeds up the progress of [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Workers[COLOR_REVERT] by 50% and also unlocks the Civic of the same name, providing a large boost to food collection at the cost of military production.
TXT_KEY_CHINESE_UNIFICATION_TECH_CURRENC: [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Currency[COLOR_REVERT] is the ideal tech for those looking to make some cash, giving a [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Great Merchant[COLOR_REVERT] to the first to discover it, while additionally giving every city an extra Trade Route and allowing the construction of the [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Bank[COLOR_REVERT] Building.
TXT_KEY_CHINESE_UNIFICATION_TECH_MILITAR: [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Militarism[COLOR_REVERT] eases the task of the conqueror, allowing Units to move more quickly over Roads, providing a free [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Great General[COLOR_REVERT] to to first to research it and also giving a massive (but costly) boost to military production through the [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Professional Army[COLOR_REVERT] Civic.
TXT_KEY_CHINESE_UNIFICATION_TECH_CALLIGR: A cultured tech with internal improvement in mind, [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Calligraphy[COLOR_REVERT] gives a [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Great Artist[COLOR_REVERT] to the first to discover, unlocks the Production-boosting and Maintenance-reducing [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]State Property[COLOR_REVERT] Civic, and the Happiness-based [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Theatre[COLOR_REVERT] Building.
TXT_KEY_CHINESE_UNIFICATION_TECH_CONSTRU: Important for economic purposes, the [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Construction[COLOR_REVERT] tech provides a free [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Great Engineer[COLOR_REVERT] Unit to the first to research it, bridges all rivers (so that they won't stop movement when traveling via road) and allows the building of the [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Underground Tomb[COLOR_REVERT] National Wonder, which reduces War Weariness and provides free Specialists to all cities.
TXT_KEY_CHINESE_UNIFICATION_TECH_MACHINE: [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Machinery[COLOR_REVERT] is an important military tech, unlocking the [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Catapult[COLOR_REVERT] Siege unit, the War Weariness-reducing and production-providing [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Absolutism[COLOR_REVERT] Civic, and finally the scientific [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Observatory[COLOR_REVERT] Building.
TXT_KEY_CHINESE_UNIFICATION_TECH_LEGALIS: [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Legalism[COLOR_REVERT] is for the iron-fisted general. The Civic of the same name gives a huge bonus to experience at the cost of Happiness, while also allowing the construction of the improved anti-Melee [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Crossbowman II[COLOR_REVERT] Unit.
TXT_KEY_CHINESE_UNIFICATION_TECH_MERITOC: The [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Meritocracy[COLOR_REVERT] tech is very important for economics and diplomacy. It unlocks the [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Educated Elite[COLOR_REVERT] Civic, providing 2 free Specialists to all cities as well as the science-boosting [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]University[COLOR_REVERT] Building. But its most important facet is that it allows the building of the [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Emperor's Council[COLOR_REVERT] World Wonder, which puts the Diplomatic Victory condition in play.
TXT_KEY_CHINESE_UNIFICATION_TECH_INDEPEN: A military tech, [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Independent Cavalry[COLOR_REVERT] increases the movement rate of Naval units by 1, but more importantly unlocks the very powerful [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Heavy Cavalry II[COLOR_REVERT] Mounted Unit.
TXT_KEY_CHINESE_UNIFICATION_TECH_MOHISM_: [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Mohism[COLOR_REVERT] has a dual use: for the economy-minded it allows the usage of the Civic option of the same name which provides a huge boost to research. Additionally, it allows the building of the ultimate anti-Mounted Unit, the [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Polearm III[COLOR_REVERT].
TXT_KEY_CHINESE_UNIFICATION_TECH_WATER_W: The [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Water Works[COLOR_REVERT] technology is all about growth. It allows the creation of [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Farm[COLOR_REVERT] plot Improvements without Irrigation or a source of fresh water, but more importantly increases the amount of Food produced by all [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Farms[COLOR_REVERT] by 1.
TXT_KEY_CHINESE_UNIFICATION_TECH_STEEL_S: [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Steel[COLOR_REVERT] is among the final military techs, unlocking the City-devastating [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Swordsman II[COLOR_REVERT], while also providing extra production when Forests are cleared by Workers.
TXT_KEY_CHINESE_UNIFICATION_SOME_TIPS: [NEWLINE][BOLD]Diplomacy:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]In this scenario, diplomacy is the key to success - whether you're leading a group of Civs into victory or are the target of everyone else is determined by your relations with the states you share the map with. Everyone is out to win control of China, and getting your neighbors to work with you rather than eye you suspiciously will be difficult. But you have a powerful tool: your [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Family Bloodline[COLOR_REVERT].[PARAGRAPH:2]Your Family Bloodline (that is, your Religion) is your way of manipulating neighboring states into becoming your friends and allies. Acquiring Open Borders and then sending your [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Family Emissaries[COLOR_REVERT] (Missionaries) is an important way of spreading your influence. But sometimes other Civs won't even be willing to grant you access to their territory. While troublesome, there remains a tactic available: you may change your OWN State Bloodline to match THEIRS. This will provide an immediate boost in relations which will give you an opening to more fruitful cooperation in the future. This may even be done many times to befriend multiple Civs, but beware the impact of this maneuver on your current allies![PARAGRAPH:2]Victory is possible through Diplomacy, as well as by Conquest and (if the time limit is reached) by Score. Winning in this way requires constructing the [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Emperor's Council[COLOR_REVERT] World Wonder. Once built, two votes will be held, one to determine the Council Leader and then for who should become the Emperor of China. The Council Leader will always be one of the two possible candidates for becoming Emperor. It is possible for no one to be elected or even to lose, so manage the relations with your friends and foes carefully![NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Battle:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Compared with warfare in a normal game of Civilization 4, combat in this scenario may seem to be quite a bit more difficult to handle. This was an era of history very much focused on defense and the use of massive armies to achieve small gains. But there are ways to avoid losing scores of men over minor objectives.[PARAGRAPH:2]As with a normal game, [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Swordsmen[COLOR_REVERT] are important for killing City defenders. Bombardment of enemy strongholds to wear down their defenses is vital for capturing them. [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Catapults[COLOR_REVERT] are not available until somewhat late in the game, but the [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Galley[COLOR_REVERT] Naval Unit is able to Bombard cities from the many navigable rivers which flow through China. Use them wisely and you will be rewarded.[PARAGRAPH:2]One final warning: If on the periphery of civilization, beware Barbarian attacks!
TXT_KEY_GAME_OPTION_NO_GOODY_HUTS_HELP: Random map generator does not place any tribal villages ("goody huts") on the map
TXT_KEY_BARBARIAN_NAVAL_MESSAGE: Naval Units can only be purchased when the camp unit is adjacent to water.
TXT_KEY_NEW_GREEKWAR_TECH_ADVANCED_SAILI: [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Advanced Sailing[COLOR_REVERT] allows the creation of the [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Trireme[COLOR_REVERT] naval unit and the [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Drydock[COLOR_REVERT] building.
TXT_KEY_NEW_GREEKWAR_TECH_IMPROVED_FORMA: [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Improved Formations I[COLOR_REVERT] allows the creation of the [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Hoplite[COLOR_REVERT] unit, which is superior to the [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Spearman.[COLOR_REVERT]

[COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Improved Formations II[COLOR_REVERT] allows the creation of the [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Phalanx[COLOR_REVERT] unit, which is superior to the [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Spearman[COLOR_REVERT] and [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Hoplite[COLOR_REVERT]. It also allows construction of the [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Military Encampment[COLOR_REVERT] building, which increases ground units' experience.
TXT_KEY_MISC_ATTITUDE_RIVAL_VASSAL: %D1: "We are worried about our rivals being vassals to your empire!"
TXT_KEY_DENIAL_VASSAL: Sorry, it's out of our hands.
TXT_KEY_VIKINGS_RANSOM_CITY: Would you like to ransom this city back to its original owner? (If you attack a city you have previously ransomed, no one will accept your ransom offer in the future.)
TXT_KEY_VIKINGS_RANSOM_PAID: You have been paid a ransom of %d1 gold.
TXT_KEY_CONCEPT_GREAT_GENERALS_PEDIA: [H1]Great Generals[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Great Generals are military leaders that emerge as your civilization gains combat experience. When you have won enough battles to reach a certain threshold of total experience, a [LINK=UNIT_GREAT_GENERAL]Great General[\LINK] appears in one of your cities. Each Great General requires twice the amount of combat experience that was needed to generate the one before.[PARAGRAPH:2]Once generated, you can turn your Great General into a Warlord by joining him with another unit in the field. That action also distributes a one-time experience bonus to units in the same tile. The unit receiving the Warlord can be upgraded at no cost, and retains all of its experience when doing so. The unit also gains access to some special promotions not normally available, such as [LINK=PROMOTION_COMBAT6]Combat VI[\LINK], [LINK=PROMOTION_MEDIC3]Medic III[\LINK], [LINK=PROMOTION_TACTICS]Tactics[\LINK], [LINK=PROMOTION_LEADERSHIP]Leadership[\LINK], and [LINK=PROMOTION_MORALE]Morale[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2]Alternatively, you can use your Great General to construct a [LINK=BUILDING_MILITARY_ACADEMY]military academy[\LINK] in a city. That city receives a production bonus when building military units.[PARAGRAPH:2]Finally, a Great General can join a city as a [LINK=SPECIALIST_GREAT_GENERAL]Great Military Instructor[\LINK]. New units constructed in that city immediately receive bonus experience points.
TXT_KEY_CONCEPT_VASSAL_STATES_PEDIA: [H1]Vassal States[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]A vassal state is one that has sworn allegiance to another state, providing its master state with some benefits in exchange for the master's pledge to protect and promote the vassal's welfare. [PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Benefits of Vassal Agreements[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]A vassal agreement results in some extra [LINK=CONCEPT_HAPPINESS]happiness[\LINK] throughout the master's empire, as well as some unhappiness for the vassal.[PARAGRAPH:2]Other benefits for the master include a right of passage through vassal territory, and visibility inside all vassal cities. In addition, the master's units heal as fast as they heal in his own territory, and can take full advantage of the vassal's fortifications.[PARAGRAPH:2]The master has the right to demand access to any [LINK=CONCEPT_RESOURCES]resource[\LINK] under vassal control, even if it is their only one. However, there is one catch. If the vassal refuses to pay this tribute, the agreement immediately ends and a state of [LINK=CONCEPT_WAR]war[\LINK] automatically results between the two parties. That is the only case where a state of war can result between a master state and a vassal state. Normally, the two parties are prevented from attacking each other and in addition if the master goes to war against a third party, the vassal automatically enters the war on the side of the master. Vassal states do not have the power to declare war or make peace on their own.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Cost of Vassal Agreements[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]When possessing vassals, the Master civilization incurs a higher [LINK=CONCEPT_MAINTENANCE]maintenance[\LINK] cost for its own cities. This costs increases as the number of vassal cities under his control increases. (Note that the master doesn't pay maintenance for the vassal's cities - he just pays extra maintenance for his civ's cities.)[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Types of Vassal Agreements[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]During peace time, a civilization can offer to become a vassal of a more powerful civilization with knowledge of [LINK=TECH_FEUDALISM]Feudalism[\LINK]. This is a temporary agreement that can be broken by the vassal (but not by the master) after 10 turns. For this type of peaceful vassalage, when the agreement is signed, any civilization at war with either of the two parties at is automatically at war with both parties.[PARAGRAPH:2]During wartime, a vassal agreement results in capitulation. [BOLD]Capitulation[\BOLD] has the same effects as peaceful vassalage, but it cannot be broken by the vassal state even after 10 turns, unless the vassal state grows to more than half of the land area and population of the master state. Capitulation may also be annulled by the vassal if the vassal state loses half of its land area since the time the agreement was signed. Capitulation forces the vassal state to immediately adopt the master's war/peace state against third parties.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Victory Conditions[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]In terms of [LINK=CONCEPT_VICTORY]victory conditions[\LINK] and score, the master state gets credit for half of the land and population of the vassal state and the vassal state gets credit for the other half. (Note, however, that acquiring vassals is not a necessarily a ticket to an easy domination victory, because the higher [LINK=CONCEPT_MAINTENANCE]maintenance[\LINK] cost for your own cities [see above] may drag your economy to a halt.)
TXT_KEY_CONCEPT_IRRIGATION_PEDIA: [H1]Irrigation[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2][LINK=IMPROVEMENT_FARM]Farms[\LINK] require irrigation in order to provide their full [LINK=CONCEPT_FOOD]food[\LINK] benefits. Irrigation can be achieved by building the farm adjacent to a source of fresh water, like a river, lake, or oasis.[PARAGRAPH:2][LINK=TECH_CIVIL_SERVICE]Civil Service[\LINK] enables irrigated farms to become a source of irrigation themselves. That allows you to bring irrigation to distant locations by building a chain of farms from the source of fresh water.[PARAGRAPH:2]With the advent of [LINK=TECH_BIOLOGY]Biology[\LINK], Farms no longer require irrigation.
TXT_KEY_IMPROVEMENT_DEFENSE_MODIFIER_EXT: [ICON_BULLET]Acts as a city for combat purposes
TXT_KEY_ROR_SCORING_POPUP: [BOLD]Scoring:[\BOLD][NEWLINE]Points in this scenario are earned through controlling Victory Resources. For every Victory Resource you control, you will earn 10 points per turn. When the game begins, each opposing Civilization controls a single Victory Resource, while your Civilization controls none. In order to win, you must capture at least 2 Victory Resources before your opponent's score gets too far ahead of your score. Good Luck!
TXT_KEY_VI_TECH_FIND_RELIC_STRATEGY: [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Research Treasure Location[COLOR_REVERT] will reveal the location of a capturable treasure unit every time it is researched.
TXT_KEY_VI_UNIT_LONGBOAT_STRATEGY: [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Longboats[COLOR_REVERT] are fast Viking ships that can transport 2 units.
TXT_KEY_BUILDING_CELTIC_DUN_STRATEGY: [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Duns[COLOR_REVERT], the Celtic replacements for [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Walls[COLOR_REVERT], increase a city's defenses against pre-gunpowder units, and gives all eligible units built in this city the [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Guerrilla I[COLOR_REVERT] promotion.
TXT_KEY_BUILDING_SPANISH_CITADEL_STRATEG: [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Citadels[COLOR_REVERT], the Spanish replacements for [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Castles[COLOR_REVERT], increase a city's defenses against pre-gunpowder units, and gives new siege units built there some extra experience.
TXT_KEY_BUILDING_ZULU_IKHANDA_STRATEGY: [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Ikhandas[COLOR_REVERT], the Zulu replacements for [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Baracks[COLOR_REVERT], grant experience points to troops built in their cities, and lower city maintenance costs.
TXT_KEY_BUILDING_MONGOL_GER_STRATEGY: [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Gers[COLOR_REVERT], the Mongol replacements for [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Stables[COLOR_REVERT], provide your mounted units with even more experience than [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Stables[COLOR_REVERT].

TXT_KEY_VIKINGS_BUILDING_KING_SAGA_PEDIA: The Norse sagas are stories about Scandinavian history and folklore. The oldest were preserved for ages through an oral tradition before finally being written down towards the end of the medieval period. Sometimes the tales are realistic; sometimes they are clearly legendary and fantastic. Sagas served as both the formal history of the Viking kings and also the mythical stories of famous heroes. The world of the sagas is strongly pagan. Fate - a dominant concept in the pre-Christian Norse religion - often plays a central role in these tales. [PARAGRAPH:2]Sagas are epic tales in prose, often with stanzas or whole poems in alliterative verse embedded within them. The style tends to be impersonal, providing only terse details with no explanation of "why" - things simply happen, and no one questions Fate. Characters are only briefly introduced, with a few simple adjectives serving to show their personality ("brave warrior", "powerful king", etc.) Relationships between characters are complex. Heroes often have to overcome seemingly impossible tasks; life is generally short and cruel; and the only thing worth pursuing is honor and glory, gained through feats of arms. Any slight or insult to someone's honor has to be avenged, in blood or money. Often the world of the supernatural played a role in the sagas, and figures from the Norse religion could figure prominently. [PARAGRAPH:2]The Kings' Sagas are a group of specific Norse sagas that describe the lives of Scandinavian kings. They were written down between the twelfth and fourteenth centuries after the Vikings had converted to Christianity. These writings are the closest thing that exists to a history of the Scandinavians during the pre-Christian Viking Age, and they have been of inestimable value to historians who study the period. [PARAGRAPH:2]The saga is not strictly a Norse literary technique, and other cultures have produced works similar in form and tone. The epics of Homer, the samurai legends of Japan, and even the cowboy tales of the American West are examples of such works. [PARAGRAPH:2]

CHANGED_TXT_KEY_CIV_ATHENS_PEDIA: [TAB]Athens is one of the great cities in world history. In ancient times its citizens made great contributions to many areas of politics, culture, and learning - including the virtual invention of philosophy, drama, science, and democracy. It can be argued that Athens has had the greatest influence of any city, state or empire on what is called, "Western Civilization." [PARAGRAPH:1]Humans have lived on the site of Athens since the Neolithic period (circa 4000 BC). According to tradition, the city-state (or "polis") of Athens was ruled by kings until roughly 1000 BC, after which it was governed by officials known as "archons," who were drawn from the ruling aristocracy. At first there were three archons, but six more were added later, bringing the total number of rulers to nine. Although originally reserved for the powerful ruling class, as time passed these offices were opened up to commoners. [PARAGRAPH:1]One archon, Solon, is credited with creating the famed Athenian democracy. Beginning in 594 BC, Solon implemented a series of liberal reforms that abolished serfdom, modified some of Athens' harsher laws, and removed some of the political restrictions on the city's economy. His reforms were so popular that Solon was subsequently given the task of rewriting Athens' constitution. While doing so, Solon significantly liberalized the Athenian government. creating a limited democracy which for the first time gave power to the non-aristocratic propertied classes. Throughout this period Athens continued to prosper and grow in size and influence. [PARAGRAPH:1]Some thirty years later, Athens' government was overthrown in a coup by a man named "Pisistratus." Though keeping many of Solon's reforms, Pisistratus ruled as a "tyrant," reserving the city-state's highest offices for friends and family. Pisistratus and his sons ruled Athens from 560-511 BC, until they were overthrown in turn by Cleisthenes, who restored Athens' limited democracy. Cleisthenes then expanded the democracy further, allowing all free Athenian men to participate in the government. Although women and slaves were still excluded from power, this was the most liberal - even radical - form of government yet seen in the world. [PARAGRAPH:1]In classical Athenian democracy, anyone (excluding women and slaves) was free to vote or serve a term in office. Most officials were chosen by lot, and government positions were rotated frequently. This was not always the most effective form of government, as it was quite common for people with no training whatsoever to find themselves elevated to positions of power and prestige, but under it the city-state thrived. [PARAGRAPH:1]As of 500 BC, much of Greece was thriving, and there were a number of successful city-states competing with Athens for primacy of the region. It wasn't until the Persian Wars of that century that Athens rose to preeminence. Athenian hoplites first fought and defeated a much larger Persian army at the Battle of Marathon in 492 BC. When the Persians returned a decade later with a much larger army, the united Greek armies were unable to halt the Persians' advance upon Athens. At the famous battle of Thermopylae, however, 300 Spartans sacrificed their lives to slow the Persians enough to allow the Athenians to evacuate their city, which the Persians subsequently entered and burned. [PARAGRAPH:1]Despite this grievous loss, the Athenian navy held firm, defeating the Persians at the Battle of Salamis in 480 BC. The combined Greek forces subsequently destroyed the invading armies and navies. As the war progressed Athens put together a loose confederation of polis, including most of the important island-based city-states, called the "Delian League," which brought the fight into Persia itself, eventually gaining the freedom of several important Greek colonies on the coast of Asia Minor and nearby islands. When the war ended the citizens of Athens returned to their city, and over the next years rebuilt it stronger and grander than ever before. In the following decades Athens became the cultural center of the Greek world. This was the golden age of the classical Athenian democracy, the era of famous figures such as Herodotus, Aeschylus, Sophocles, Euripides, and Socrates. [PARAGRAPH:1]During this period Athens became the dominant city-state in Greece. It possessed a lucrative trading empire, which was protected by its powerful navy, and it gradually transformed the Delian League into an empire, the other city-states in the League required to pay Athens tribute. This alarmed many of the other Greek polis, which, under the leadership of Sparta - the greatest land power in Greece - banded together in the "Spartan Alliance" to counter Athens' growing might. [PARAGRAPH:1]In 431 BC war broke out between the Delian League and the Spartan Alliance. commanded by Pericles, Athens' greatest statesman and general, Athens won numerous victories, but was unable to ever deliver the knockout blow needed to force the Spartans to surrender. Upon Pericles' death - from a plague that badly weakened Athens - command of the Athenian government and armed forces fell to less able hands, and the Athenians found themselves in a thirty-year war of attrition which grew ever more bitter and bloody as the years passed. [PARAGRAPH:1]Protected from direct assault by its Long Walls, and supplied by its offshore empire (inaccessible to the enemy), Athens survived the long war in fairly good shape (though its democratic institutions were gradually undermined). It is quite possible that Athens could have eventually forced its opponents into peace, if her people hadn't decided to send off a large portion of Athens' military forces on a foolish adventure of conquest to Sicily in 415 BC. During the campaign the Athenian army was obliterated, and its navy destroyed in detail. Though Athens continued to resist for some ten years, its defeat was inevitable. Athens finally surrendered to Sparta in 404 BC, its fleet in shambles and its overseas empire destroyed. [PARAGRAPH:1]Although Athens was able to recover briefly in the following decades, its golden age was past and it would never again reach the heights it attained before the disastrous war with Sparta. In 338 BC, Athens (along with the rest of Greece) was conquered by Philip of Macedon. The city would never again see independence, and Greece would spend most of the next 2,000 years under foreign rule - governed in turn by Macedonia, Rome, Byzantium, and the Ottoman Empire. In 1829 AD Greece would finally win independence - and Athens was naturally chosen as the new state's capital city.
